text: Inside the small, glass-enclosed room, the MAN sets a pen ink on a writing table. He opens a leather-bound book, th cover of which reads:
He inks the pen and begins to write.
April 21st, 1905. The die is cast...

head_text.subj: ON A STRETCH OF WHITE SAND BEACH

text: TWELVE MEN stand in a line. Some hold kerosene lamps. All are dressed in black, like their mood.

A vote has been taken and our decision made. I have volunteered to carry-out the deed, much to the dismay of my Erica and the children... MALONE moves down the line of men. The last of them hands him an official-looking PARCHMENT, rolled and tied with a ribbon. Without ceremony, MALONE turns and walks towards
Where two OARSMEN shove a longboat into the surf. MALONE gets in, and we’1l notice some cargo, lashed-down under a tarp.
My mind races with the thought of what I must now do. Of what must be done. And as they put out to sea, MALONE looks back to find... ELEVEN MEN standing on the beach. Silent. Watching.

STEADY ROWING is the only SOUND we hear. MALONE sits rapt thought, when something up ahead catches his eye. The OARSMEN stop rowing and we REVERSE ANGLE to reveal an advancing FOG BANK, not 50 fee ahead. The OARSMEN look to MALONE.

Afraid of a little fog, are we? He nods at them to press on. They pick up the rhythm agai disappearing into the swirling mist... INT. A SHIP’S HOLD ~- NIGHT MOVING through the belly of a clipper ship, a labyrinth o light and shadow, lit by hanging lanterns swaying from th rafters. There are PEOPLE in here, scurrying about, performing wha we'd guess are their assigned duties. They are oddly dres in cloak and shroud, and we cannot see their faces. A MAN, dressed like the others, descends the creaky stair into the hold. His name is BLAKE, and we can tell by the deference paid him, he is their leader. He walks amongst them with his lantern, offering a gentle on the back or a quiet nod...

BLAKE enters the room. A WOMAN sits at a dressing table, facing away from us, brushing her long, dark hair. We not her HAIRBRUSH -- made of pure gold, engraved with INTRICA PATTERNS... On hearing BLAKE enter, she pulls her shroud up over her and turns. We see her only in profile, and from this angl she is unmistakably beautiful. BLAKE walks over to her. She looks up at him, uneasy. Reassuringly, he reaches out to touch her face.

Don't worry. This is a new beginning. For all of us. When he pulls his hand away, there is milky-white MAGGOT wriggling on his fingertip. This doesn’t seem to bother h in the least, as he flicks the thing away. Then he leans in to kiss her and his lantern lights the of her face we couldn’t quite see... ...covered in pus-filled boils and sagging, gangrenous tissue. But her eyes are alive and filled with love for t man. They kiss.

It's as if we’ve been swallowed whole by a thick and undulating fog, creeping in on us from every side. Again, PICK UP the ROWING SOUND... ...which seems to be coming at us, then we could swear it moving away. We’re becoming more and more disoriented now Up is down and down is up and soon the SOUND seems to wra around us like the fog itself, when...

PIERCES the mist. There’s a DULL THUD as the LONGBOAT ban into something not yet seen. The OARSMEN stow their oars MALONE raises his lantern and WE SEE WHAT THEY'VE HIT... THE BATTERED HULL OF THE CLIPPER SHIP. Light spills from tiny portholes belowdecks, illuminating name painted on her bow:
MALONE draws a pistol. The OARSMEN look surprised. MALONE reaches out, RAPPING on the Dane’s hull with the butt:
CLOSE ON a pair of embracing hands. WIDEN to reveal they belong to BLAKE and the WOMAN. He gets up to leave, but s doesn’t want to let go.
It’s going to be fine. I promise you with all my heart.
MALONE sits in the LONGBOAT, pistol stowed, bobbing along the DANE, when A CLOAKED SHAPE leans out over the gunwale BLAKE.
Williams?

(looking away) Yes. BLAKE disappears momentarily. A leather SATCHEL comes fly over the rail, practically hits MALONE in the head. MALONE takes out the PARCHMENT we saw earlier, places it the satchel, flings it back up on deck.
Leave the gold on deck and get your people down below. I/’11 not ~ subject myself to your wretched... A rope-ladder is dropped over the side. The OARSMEN rise.

Wait. MALONE takes out a knife, slashes open the tarp, revealin the cargo: three large cans marked KEROSENE. The shocked OARSMEN look to MALONE -- nobody said anything about this EXT. ELIZABETH DANE’S DECK ~- NIGHT First one up, MALONE lifts his lantern. The deck appears empty, save for a rusted metal CHEST. MALONE goes over an flips open the lid to find it brimming with GOLD COINS. He dips into it, letting the cold wealth run through his fingers, startled when HE HEARS SOMETHING... MALONE holds up his lantern, sees BLAKE’s cloaked shape standing at the bow.
You’re not Williams.
No. But I represent his interests. His, and the rest of the town fathers. MALONE'S hand slips behind his back, producing the PISTOL
We want the rest of your gold, Blake. All of it.
’ The deal we made was more than fair. Take what's there, and go. MALONE nods to the OARSMEN who crack open the KEROSENE, b dousing the Dane’s wooden deck.
In God's name, what kind of people are you? MALONE lights a wooden match with his thumbnail, holds it over the deck -- something for BLAKE to think about.
Alright! I’11 need to go below.
(blows out the match) Go on. But if you try anything, the ship burns. MALONE turns the pistol on his own men.
Go with him. ~
Please... Don’t make us go down there... With them.
Down there... {cocks the pistol) Or up here.

We descend into the ship's hold, crowded with BLAKE'S peo The OARSMEN follow BLAKE, covering their noses at the unbearable stench. EXT. ELIZABETH DANE’S DECK - LATER ~- NIGHT MALONE stands waiting impatiently at the hatchway. One of the OARSMEN starts to come up the ladder. MALONE puts his boot on the man’s shoulder. .

Gold first. Then you. A heavy CHEST is thrust upwards. MALONE grabs it by the handle... The OARSMAN starts back up the ladder, when MALONE kicks in the teeth, sending him tumbling back down. MALONE kicks over a full can of KEROSENE, which goes spil into the hold. BLAKE looks out from the shadow of his clo EYES dark and malevolent, fixing MALONE with a cursed sta MALONE recoils at this, dropping his lantern into the hol We hear a WHUMPH as the kerosene ignites. And then we hea the SCREAMS as MALONE slams the hatch shut. He shoots the bolt across and BASHES THE HASP, rendering it useless, sealing them in. Forever. In a hurry now, MALONE slides the first chest to the edge the deck, but it’s heavy and he’1]l never get it down the ladder by himself. In a greedy panic, he spots the Dane’s lifeboat, suspended by ropes at deck level.

MALONE has loaded both chests into the lifeboat. SMOKE billows up through the planks of the Dane’s deck. People SCREAMING down below, POUNDING for a way out. MALONE gets into the lifeboat, takes his knife and SLASHE the ropes holding him aloft... But one of the ropes SNAGS in a pulley, dropping the bow sharply. The weight of the chests sends them SMASHING through the first two bench seats, threatening to crash r through the bow and into the water. MALONE LUNGES FOR THEM as the lids POP OPEN, sending hund of gold coins to the bottom of the sea, when The hung rope FREES ITSELF. The life boat falls, smacking down into the water. Relieved, MALONE turns his back on t smoldering ship, picking gold coins off the floor of the lifeboat, when A HAND SMASHES THROUGH ONE OF THE PORTHOLES, burnt flesh dripping from the bone, locking MALONE in a death grip! Out of his wits, MALONE struggles to break free, HACKING the hideous hand, bashing at it with an oar as the SCREAM from inside the DANE build into an unholy frenzy. With a last, bone-crunching WHACK, the hand withers and MALONE is free. He rows away from the doomed ship using a his strength, gliding past. a barnacle-encrusted BUOY... And WE HOLD ON THE BUOY, bobbing in the ocean, as a hund years of time and tide pass before our eyes... A SLEEK WHITE CHARTER BOAT powers past the BUOY, splashin with a glassy sheet of water. NICK CASTLE, 20, is on the FLYBRIDGE, at the helm of this foot luxo SPORT-FISHING BOAT. His hair is blown back by t wind, emphasizing his raw good looks. His SWEATSHIRT tell us who he’s working for: ANTONIO BAY SPORT-FISHING CHARTE WORKING THE REAR OF THE BOAT is BRETT SPOONER, 20, Nick's best friend and fellow employee. Simple, honest, made of good stuff, SPOONER’S got a mop of surfer’s hair, and has yet lost all his baby fat... SPOONER uses a mean-looking BONING KNIFE to splay open a yellowfin, while TWO SUNBURNED FISHERMEN drink beer after day on the water. SPOONER offers up a slice of raw tuna.
Sushi? The FISHERMEN decline, so SPOONER happily sucks it down, as the boat breezes by us, we'll notice the name painted stern: SEAGRASS.
As the SEAGRASS glides-in under the harbor lights, NICK begins STRIPPING down to his boxers...
NICK expertly parks the boat in its slip. He shuts down t engines, grabs his clothes and slides down the ladder ont the deck, where the FISHERMEN are gathering their gear.
(in a hurry) Thanks for your business, guys. See you next year. Hustle it up, would you, Spooner? SPOONER pulls two big fish from the FREEZER in the hold.
Dude. Nice underpants.
SPOONER enters the cabin, looking for NICK.
Yo, Nick!
In here.

NICK stands shirtless, lean and muscled, hair wet from a shower. He buttons his jeans, straps on his watch, checks the time -- he’s way late. SPOONER dances into the doorway, stands beside NICK in th mirror. He pulls his shirt up over his considerable belly
Look -- twins.
Dream on.
Not you an’ me. These. SPOONER starts tracing little circles around his nipples.
Don’t bug me, Spooner. I’m late.
For what? We still got decks to swab.
Elizabeth's coming home tonight. I’m picking her up at the train.
Wait, wait, wait. I remember you telling me this...
So you do have one brain cell left...
...to which I think’I responded, her mom will slice off your teeny weeny little balls, and have herself a Nick's special. (of£ NICK’S look) Testicle on rye.
Screw her mom.
I tried. I think my Soloflex abs were too much for her. SPOONER picks up NICK’S brush, starts brushing his own mo It’s hopeless.
I thought Elizabeth and her mom ~ were in some big hatefest.
I don't know. Just back me up on this, alright? Hose down the boat and gas it up for tomorrow. That way, we won't get fired.
We?
Yeah, we. Like, we need to keep our jobs so we can buy our own boat some day...
Oh, that we.
(out the door) See you at the beach party.
By the way, how do you plan to handle the thing between you and Stevie? NICK stops, turns, puts his hands on SPOONER’S shoulders.
Spooner. That was a one-time thing. And I regret it. (checks his watch again) I am so late.

NICK drives down MAIN STREET of the quaint little coastal town, past Jimmy's Chowder Shack and the Rainy Ale Tavern  10. He passes the Tasty-Freeze and Tisdale's Hardware, and th we notice the BLEACHERS erected on either side of the str and the BANNERS proclaiming Antonio Bay’s 100th birthday celebration.
As a low-hanging ground fog rounds a corner and begins spreading towards us. It flows over sidewalks and into th streets...

NICK drives the road out of town, a can of Bud between hi legs, about to take a swig, when he notices A SHERIFF’S PICKUP TRUCK parked on a berm beside the road The door is open and we can see the SHERIFF walking up to A BIG FOR SALE sign, planted in the ground. WORDING on th sign: 50 acres, prime development site, artist's renderin of some cookie-cutter condos, phone number, etc. NICK slows, watching as the SHERIFF hammers something ont the sign. He yells out the window.
What‘re you doin to that sign?

He looks over and smirks. The brass bar opposite his badg reads MALONE. In his 40’s, he was handsome once, but TOM MALONE now has the look of a man who has lost his edge... He takes a step towards NICK’S truck, and we can see the plaque he just nailedon: SOLD
What’re you doin way out here, Hotrod?
Just goin for a ride. Somebody finally buy that land, or what?
Don’t you worry about it. Let’s just say I won't be Sheriff of this dump much longer... NICK eyes him, trying to put it together...  11.
‘What the hell’re you lookin at? (then) I don’t smell beer in that truck, do I?
No sir. Not unless it’s Root Beer.
That‘s good. Now you go on and enjoy your ride. And be sure and obey those little white signs with the numbers in ‘em.
Yes sir. (under his breath) Prick. NICK smiles and drives off.
NICK swigs his beer now, scenery whipping by outside the window. He shifts the truck into high gear.
The headlights illuminate the winding road, cutting throu dense green forest. Pockets of MIST swirl and drift acros the road... From the RADIO in the dash, we HEAR a sensual female voic

It’s nine-thirty on a beautiful Friday night in Antonio Bay. I’m Stevie Wayne, and I’m gonna go a little ‘old school’ on you tonight. Here's a track from [Ramones, etc.] on KAB, 94.5, and streaming over the web at kabtunes.com. KAB -- your alternative to the modern music establishment.
(smiling) ...the voice that launched a thousand ships.  12. MUSIC comes over the radio. NICK reaches down to turn up volume, and when he glances up:
It's a white-out. WHEN SUDDENLY,

head_text.subj: A GIRL APPEARS IN THE MIST

text: NICK SWERVES and hits the brakes, watching her in the headlights as he passes by. She’s hitch-hiking, a suitcas at her feet. And she’s hot. He checks his watch again, looks back at the GIRL as if t And now she’s eyeing him, too...
Shit. He puts on the brakes, makes a’u-turn and goes back for h He pulls over, rolls down his window.
"Hi.
Hi, yourself.
Don’t you know hitch-hiking is dangerous? The GIRL just shrugs.
You want a ride?
But you’re headed in the wrong direction.
(with a big smile) Not anymore. . The GIRL picks up her suitcase, sashays around the front the truck and opens the door. She is barely 20, beautiful and strong -- a dream of a girl-next-door.
You're not a freak or anything. Are you?  13.
Yeah. Actually I am.

(smiling) She gets in and closes the door. She looks straight ahead but they aren’t going anywhere. She finally turns to NICK, who looks at her with gleaming almost mesmeric eyes. She starts to say something, when h reaches out, tracing the line of her jaw, her lips. Suddenly she’s all over him and he just rolls with it. So they are reaching inside each other’s clothes, popping buttons, sliding down in the seat...
God, I missed you... (stops kissing him) And Nick?
Yes, Elizabeth...

Next time, don’t be late. They go at it again, quickly disappearing from view. CAMERA SLOWLY BOOMS UP from the truck, RISING through the trees, to reveal the STARS, the craggy COASTLINE, and a familiar-looking LIGHTHOUSE out on the point. Its BEACON strakes the horizon, fingering the darkness, ~ moving on, as we HEAR...

It's a little after 10 o’clock and I'm Stevie Wayne, your very own beacon in-the-night... CAMERA races at the LIGHTHOUSE with lightning speed, BLIN for an instant by the LIGHT on top as it whooshes by agai and now we're INSIDE that same small, glass-enclosed room at the top of eld stone lighthouse -- now the broadcast booth of KAB. CLOSE ON STEVIE WAYNE -- 20’s, funkily sensual, a young J Jett type. Her hair is. up and she wears a cut-up Ramones shirt. She uses her bare foot to adjust the mike.  14.

I'm high tonight in the KAB lighthouse on Spivey Point... and I’m being paid the big bucks to remind everybody this Sunday marks Antonio Bay’s 100th anniversary... Dammit ! PULL BACK to find STEVIE sitting at her console, one foot the board, painting her toe nails with deep purple polish She grabs a kleenex to dab a smudge...

.-you can say that on the radio nowadays. Anyway, by now you know the drill. The big shin-dig is planned for Sunday, with a surprise performance by a local band you won’t wanna miss. So go, she said, and if you don’t have a date, you can always take me along to keep you company. She flips a switch and another SONG begins to play. Instantly, the phones LIGHT UP. STEVIE looks flatly at th flashing lights.
I don’t mean literally, you morons.
The lights on the MERRY-MARKET SIGN go out. A HAND turns CLOSED SIGN in the window. The GROUND FOG hovers outside door...

A BAG BOY picks up his broom, cranks the volume on his ra as the song Stevie just cued plays in the b.g. He goes to straighten a display of canned goods, when something make » him stop... He looks around the store, eying the creepy old curios dangling from the ceiling, hanging on walls, etc. -- Shaking it off, he starts to sweep, when the lights insid the soda cases begin to flicker and buzz. BOTTLES start CLINKING together on the shelves. The whole place starts to. RATTLE AND HUM now, as stuff falls and b in the aisles.  15.

Shit! It’s the big one! He drops his broom and races for the exit, when he sees: THE AUTOMATIC DOORS slamming open and shut all on their o fast, and erratic -- lethal even -- and when he turns, he sees something that freezes him in his tracks: MICROWAVE POPCORN starts to POP. Still in the packages. Right on the shelf.

The screen on the ATM begins BUZZING with a weird, sepia- FLUX. It looks like there’s an IMAGE trying to form somewhere in there, but then we hear the KA-CHUNK of the dispenser, as TWENTIES begin spitting from the machine. An OLD LADY passes by, her eyeglasses on a decorative cha around her neck. At first she just keeps walking, but whe she realizes no one is watching, she goes back, scooping bills into her purse.
Closed. Dark. The AIR HOSE DING-DING’s. But there’s nobod there. One of the gas NOZZLES falls off the pump, begins dischar GASOLINE, which slowly spreads across the parking lot...
Through the window, we see DOGS GOING NUTS in their cages barking at the moon, spinning, chasing their tails...
There’s a cheery SIGN out front, with a digital TIME/TEMP display. The thing is going haywire -- 34 o’clock, 299 degrees, etc. And for the briefest moment, we could swear spells out a word: DANE

A burned-out BEACHCOMBER in a tattered navy pea coat shuf up the beach. In one hand is a METAL DETECTOR, which he waves over the sand. In the other is a FLASK. He takes a drink and we notice his thrashed sea captain's and a headset that attaches to the metal detector. He gru as the booze goes down, looks up with bloodshot eyes.  16.

MUSIC PLAYS OVER a dozen young PARTIERS, hanging out arou blazing BONFIRE, guzzling beer, making out, passing a doo etc. NICK and ELIZABETH are here, along with their friends SEA REED and EMILY MOSS. NICK puts his arm around ELIZABETH, pulls her close.
Hey. You happy?
Mmmm-hmmm .
You look good enough to eat, you know that.
Bon a petit... NICK gets an evil smile. She kisses him deeply. Young lov The SONG we’ve been listening to ENDS, and we hear STEVIE VOICE over the airwaves:

It’s almost midnight on KAB, I'm still Stevie Wayne, and I'd like to send a shout out to my good friend, Elizabeth Williams, Antonio Bay’s favorite college girl. Welcome home, Lizzy. This one’s for you. A new song PLAYS. The friends raise their beers, ad libbi toasts, which ELIZABETH shyly accepts.
Stevie’s extremely cool. SEAN saunters up with fresh beers, shoots NICK a look he pretends not to see. He hands ELIZABETH a beer.
Yeah, Elizabeth. Welcome back to dullsville. Hey Nickster. Let's go water the sand... NICK and SEAN get up, move off into the darkness. EMILY scoots closer to ELIZABETH.
Something nor EMILY
So. What’s it like?
What?
College guys. The parties. The dorms. You know...
It’s fine, I guess.
Fine? I thought it'd be like, exotic. And glamorous.

Well, let’s see. I’ve gained five pounds from the dorm food. There’s a big, hairy Russian chick on my floor that stares at me in the showers, and two of my professors have hit on me, only one of whom is male.
(dreamy) That's awesome. Sure beats Antonio Bay... smiles a sad little smile, suddenly looks away...
Did you hear that?
What?

I dunno, I thought I... Nevermind. sweeps behind ELIZABETH in a blur, but neither she sees it. shrugs if off, POPS open her beer, when COMES HURTLING out of the darkness landing SMACK IN EMILY’S LAP -- viscera and mandibles and shell -- like th skittering ALIEN on the guy’s face in the movie... EMILY and it’s just ELIZABETH JUMP UP SCREAMING, until they realize a DEAD SPINY LOBSTER upside-down in the sand.  18. NICK and SEAN run up laughing, high-fiving each other.
Hardy-har, children.
That's so not cool!
You shoulda seen your faces. Suddenly, A PALE WHITE FACE appears in the darkness behin them, seems to hover there.
Boo! The whole group JUMPS! It’s the BEACHCOMBER. NICK © Jesus, Machen! What the hell do you want? MACHEN looks around, sizing up the partiers with lusty ey
I'll take a Bud if you got it.
Hey, Machen. I got yer beer. Go fetch. SEAN fakes like he’s gonna throw the can, when ELIZABETH takes it, hands it politely to MACHEN.
Thank you..
You're welcome. MACHEN guzzles some beer which runs down his chin, while eyeballs the taped-together metal detector.

You been up and down the beach with that thing every day since I can remember. What the hell’re you looking for? MACHEN reaches into his pocket, pulls out a gleaming GOLD COIN, exactly like the ones we saw in the opening.  19.
More of these...
What is it?
You sure you wanna know?
What? Are we gonna get a curse or something? | Oooocoochhhh. They all laugh, but not MACHEN.
It's the coin of greed. The coin of lust. The coin of doom. The PARTIERS look at each other.
You're freaky-deaky, old man. MACHEN checks his watch.
Five minutes till midnight. Not much time left... MACHEN turns towards the fire, staring into it.
In five minutes, it’11 be the twenty-first of April.
So? MACHEN puts the coin on his tongue, the takes a swig of b

They’11 get nothin’ from me. Now MACHEN just stares, transe-like, into the crackling f There is a hushed silence as the PARTIERS just stare at t BEACHCOMBER. Only the HISS of the flames and then... THE SOUND OF AN ENGINE blasts open the silence as

head_text.subj: SPOONER DRIVES THE SEAGRASS RIGHT UP ONTO THE BEACH

text: He jumps off onto the sand, obviously drunk. He’s got a camcorder in his hand, taping two BEAUTIFUL BLONDES in sweatshirts and bikini bottoms... And as they come off the boat, we realize one of the girl BRUNETTE, is actually wearing a blonde wig, which is star to fall off her head.
(videotaping) Ladies. We have arrived. NICK comes running up, can’t believe his eyes.
Nick! You know the twins. Mandi and Brandi.
They’re not twins!
They’re not?
What the hell are you doing, Spooner! SPOONER turns the camera on NICK.
This is Nick Castle. As you can see, Nick’s a bit pisssed off right now. Let’s find out why...
Shut that thing off, shithead.

(still taping) Wait a minute. Up there on the beach! Is that a... Yes. There's a party going on. Young men and women, cavorting around half-naked, polluting their bodies and minds. God, that sounds like fun. Let’s investigate!
Give me the keys, Spooner. SPOONER strolls past him with the TWINS in tow.  21.
Relax, Nick. I left em on the boat. Nobody's gonna steal it.
NICK climbs onto the flybridge. SEAN, ELIZABETH and EMILY walk down to the boat.
Want some help? NICK reaches in his pocket, tosses ELIZABETH his truck ke
Take my truck to your mom’s. I‘1l come get it in the morning. I’ve gotta get this boat back to the marina.
Nick? Remember when you were gonna teach me to drive a stick?
Yeah?
You never did.
Look, Nick. You guys only got a couple days together. You take Elizabeth home. I/11 get Spooner and the boat back to the marina.
No, the boat’s my responsibility.
Dude, I can handle my dad’s 42-foot Bertram. I think I can handle this. ELIZABETH looks up at NICK without coaxing, wants him to the call. Finally, he sighs and we cut To:  22.

STEVIE sorts through CD’s for tomorrow's shift, and for t first time we notice the WALL BEHIND HER, covered with a child's CRAYON DRAWINGS and construction paper ARTWORK. Beside her on the console is a photo of STEVIE with her a around a bright-eyed LITTLE BOY. STEVIE’S cellphone rings. She doesn’t check the display..
Hi Andy... MAN’S VOICE (ON PHONE) Hello, darlin.
Oh. Hi Dan.
You’re lonely over there without me, aren't you?
Remind me why I gave you my cell number again?
DAN O’BANNON sits at a bank of glowing electronics in the tiny Coast Guard weather station.
Because I’m six feet of burnin’ love?
You're five-eight, Dan. And why are you still at work?
I traded shifts so I can go to the big party on Sunday. You gonna go?
I sleep on Sundays. Now tell me why you called, or I’m gonna hang up.  23.
Tell your boss you need the day off.
I am the boss, Dan.
Okay, okay. Just thought you might like something to talk about.
I’m listening.
I got something on my doppler a minute ago.
Sounds kinky.
Looks like a fog bank about twenty miles out. Moving inland. STEVIE opens a little ACCESS WINDOW in the glass, taps a GAUGE outside the lighthouse...
Then my gauges must be wrong, ‘cause I show a wind blowing due East. What kind of fog moves against the wind?
You got me, but my radar doesn’t lie.
This is very exciting stuff, Dan.
Hey. That’s what I’m here for.
I gotta go. Buh-bye. STEVIE hangs up and hits a switch, leans into the mic.
It’s a little after midnight on KAB. Stevie here, beaming my signal across the sea. (MORE)

STEVIE (cont'd) Big Dan the Weatherman says there’s a fog bank rolling in offshore, so if I were you, I’d lock the doors and hide the keys...and whip up a pitcher of martinis while you listen to another hour of music on K.A.B. MUSIC UP as STEVIE cues another disk. She looks out over ocean, drinks a bottled water, shakes her head.
There’s no fog out there... curt TO:
SEAN is at the helm of the SEAGRASS. The SONG Stevie just cued CONTINUES over the boat's stereo.
There’s no fog out there... (yells) Spooner! You see any fog out there?
We see the TWINS dancing, laughing, etc. SPOONER pans the horizon, then turns the lens on himself...
There’s no fog out there! Back on the flybridge, SEAN continues looking anyway -- u the ENGINE starts to sputter. He checks the controls, eye going to the fuel gauge... EMPTY.
Shit! Spooner! We’re outta gas.
Dude. That sucks. SEAN whips out his cell. Display reads: NO SERVICE. Shit. He shakes his head at SPOONER, whose night is far from ruined, as he keeps right on dancing...  25.
ELIZABETH sits close to NICK as they approach the outskir of town.
As they speed by, we notice something they don’t. EVERY STREETLIGHT THEY PASS GOES OUT. And stays out...
ELIZABETH puts her hand inside his shirt, lulled by the p of the engine.
I wish I could stay at your place tonight.
You could if you really wanted to. You could do alot of things if you really wanted to.
You're not still blaming me.
(yes) No.
You know why I left Antonio Bay, Nick. I had to. The only thing I didn’t want to leave...was you. SUDDENLY, THE TRUCK’S WINDOWS EXPLODE, SHATTERING INTO A
ELIZABETH ducks, SCREAMING as glass FLIES everywhere. NIC drops down to protect her and the truck swerves to the si of the road, banging to a stop against the curb.
On NICK and ELIZABETH, hunkered down in the cab as the du settles.
You okay?
I think so.  26.
What the hell was that? And when they SIT UP... THERE'S A FIGURE LOOMING IN THE WINDOW! They both JUMP!
A travesty. A hundred-year travesty...
